awd_titl_txt: Localization and Diffusion in Open and Many Body Quantum Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The main focus of this project is the study of the effects of disorder on quantum systems. In a broader context, the work draws inspiration from the basic scientific question: "What are the effects of disorder?" This is a fundamental question relevant to any scientific model, even one in which disorder is not explicitly included. After all, any real world system is subject to a small amount of noise, and experience shows that even weak disorder may have a profound effect on the behavior of the system. The equations studied in this project arise in the theory of disordered materials, but are of general interest because of the fundamental nature of both wave motion and disorder. Progress in understanding the solutions to these equations will improve basic understanding of models of theoretical physics and applied mathematics. In addition, a central goal of the research is pedagogical: to introduce students to a fundamental subject and convey to them that mathematical and theoretical physics are vibrant, growing fields.
 
The project will proceed through a program of research on the effects of disorder in physical models. The main focus of the research is in understanding the evolution of quantum systems subject to intrinsic disorder. When disorder is weak, the expectation is that a diffusive evolution of the wave function results. At stronger disorder, it is known that localization of the wave function can occur, although the exact nature of localization in many body and open quantum systems is poorly understood. Two key goals are 1) to analyze the diffusion of waves in a weakly disordered medium over arbitrarily long times, and 2) to clarify the nature of localization in many body models.  In recent years the PI and various post-doc and student collaborators have considered the problem of wave diffusion in time-dependent random media, with the time dependence generated by a Markov process. For such models the diffusive propagation, e.g., for the tight binding Schrodinger equation, can be established by spectral analysis. One aim of the present project is to approach the time independent equation as a perturbation of these time dependent equations, which have the virtue of sharing the expected qualitative behavior. In parallel, we will study disorder induced localization in polaron type models of a interacting systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was focused on the study of disorder and noise in quantum systems.  In a broader context, this work is inspired by the basic scientific question, "What are the effects of disorder?"  This question is fundamental for any scientifc model;  after all, any real world system is subject to a small amount of noise.  And experience shows that even weak disorder may have a profound effect on the behavior of the system.


The work undertaken on this project fell in three distinct areas:

  1. Theory of Erogdic Quantum Processes.
  2. Diffusion in extended open quantum systems
  3. Theory of Anderson localization

The biggest new development from this project is the theory of Ergodic Quantum Processes (EQPs).  EQPs were introduced by the PI and Ramis Movassagh in two papers reporting on work supported by this project.  Any quantum process (e.g., the various stepsof a quantum computation, effects of noise and errors on the state, and measurements) is represented by a sequence of quantum channels. By bridging the theory of dynamical systems to quantum information, we characterizef a general class of quantum processes, which we term ‘Ergodic’.  Our papers are the first to provide important universality theorems for a vast class of (time-correlated) quantum processes in the presence of non-negligible disorder and/or decoherence. We anticipate that these papers will open up an area of research of importance to quantum information science and condensed matter physics.  Follow up work on characterizing EQPs was completed by a graduate student Lubashan Pathirana working on the project.


The study of diffusion in extended open quantum systems has been at the center of the PIs work for some time.  A graduate student Jacob Gloe working on the project studied diffusion for a quantum particle in a periodic background subject to quantum noise modeled using a so-called quantum master equation (Lindblad equation).  He was able to prove a special case of a conjecture made by the PI, Zak Tilocco and Shiwen Zhang about the magnitude of the diffusion constant at weak coupling.

Anderson localization is the well studied physical phenomenon of disorder leading to trapping (non-propagation) of time evolved quantum states.  Although well studied there remain vexing open questions.  In joint work with F. Klopp, the PI introduced a new concept, called the "onset length", for localized quantum states. Roughly the onset length is the length scale at which localization kicks in.  Unlike the localization length, it is a sample and state dependent quantity.  In our paper we study the statistics of onset lengths.  We show that the distribution satisfies an exponential upper bound.  These results have potential applications to various perturbations of localized systems, including many body systems, in which rare resonances caused by rare, large overlaps between eigenfunctions can play a role.  

Other work of the PI supported by the project gave improved estimates on the localization length for eigenfunctions of random band matrices and studied the role of localization in topological insulators. The later project, joint with Alex Bols and Jacob  Shapiro, we developed a truly novel approach to indices in topological insulators in the situation in which the naive topological indices are ill-defined because the resulting operators fail to be Fredholm (due the presence of dense point spectrum for the bulk Hamiltonian).  By defining a suitably regularized Fredholm index, we established a theory of edge indices for such systems, which is distinct from and more general than the PIs prior work with Graf and Elgart.
